articles.headline: Debate Over Risk of Driving G.M.’s Recalled Cars
articles.snippet: Some of the cars being recalled by General Motors for problems related to the ignition switch that are still being driven by their owners may still pose a danger to the owner and other motorists.
articles.abstract: Some of the cars being recalled by General Motors for problems related to the ignition switch that are still being driven by their owners may still pose a danger to the owner and other motorists.
articles.lead_paragraph: There was nothing but the car key on Jacob Hughes’s key ring.
articles.byline: By Hilary Stout and Rachel Abrams

articles.headline: Users’ Stark Reminder: As Web Grows, It Grows Less Secure
articles.snippet: The bug known as Heartbleed illustrates that the Internet is still in its youth, and vulnerable to all sorts of unseen dangers, including simple human error.
articles.abstract: The bug known as Heartbleed illustrates that the Internet is still in its youth, and vulnerable to all sorts of unseen dangers, including simple human error.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was the computer programming equivalent of misspelling Mississippi — an error at once careless, inevitable and hard for most human eyes to spot.

articles.headline: Flaw Calls for Altering Passwords, Experts Say
articles.snippet: Security researchers say consumers should make sure they change their passwords after a flaw on some websites is fixed, but figuring that out may not be easy.
articles.abstract: Security researchers say consumers should make sure they change their passwords after a flaw on some websites is fixed, but figuring that out may not be easy.
articles.lead_paragraph: A programming mistake from two years ago has forced countless websites to make fixes to protect the sensitive personal information of consumers.

articles.headline: Eye Doctors Say Their Profits Are Smaller Than Data Makes Them Look
articles.snippet: Ophthalmologists say treatments like cataract operations and an expensive macular degeneration drug skew their Medicare reimbursements.
articles.abstract: Ophthalmologists say treatments like cataract operations and an expensive macular degeneration drug skew their Medicare reimbursements.
articles.lead_paragraph: Although consumers and health experts will be poring over the newly released Medicare data for months, maybe years to come, one startling piece of information has already emerged, demonstrating some of the complexity inherent in the long-fought-over information on 880,000 health care providers across the country.
articles.byline: By Andrew Pollack and Reed Abelson

articles.headline: The Medicare Data’s Pitfalls
articles.snippet: Many doctors said they favored the sharing of Medicare payment data but worried that it left out important details.
articles.abstract: Many doctors said they favored the sharing of Medicare payment data but worried that it left out important details.
articles.lead_paragraph: The release on Wednesday of Medicare payment data is getting mixed reviews from doctors. Many say they favor sharing information but worry that the data presented by Medicare omits important details and may mislead the public and paint an unfairly negative picture of individual doctors.
articles.byline: By Denise Grady and Sheri Fink

articles.headline: Flight 370 Search Brings Satellite Company an Unaccustomed Bit of Fame
articles.snippet: Inmarsat, the company keeping tabs on the flow of information about Flight 370, has found itself thrust, uncomfortably, into the spotlight.
articles.abstract: Inmarsat, the company keeping tabs on the flow of information about Flight 370, has found itself thrust, uncomfortably, into the spotlight.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — On an enormous electronic map of the globe in the modernist headquarters of a satellite company here, two green hexagons the size of dinner plates hovered off the west coast of Australia, revealing signals from an armada of ships and planes converged in the hunt for any remains of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

articles.headline: Profiling Rules Said to Give F.B.I. Tactical Leeway
articles.snippet: The long-awaited revisions to the Justice Department’s racial profiling rules would continue to allow the F.B.I. to use that information for national security purposes.
articles.abstract: The long-awaited revisions to the Justice Department’s racial profiling rules would continue to allow the F.B.I. to use that information for national security purposes.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr.’s long-awaited revisions to the Justice Department’s racial profiling rules would allow the F.B.I. to continue many, if not all, of the tactics opposed by civil rights groups, such as mapping ethnic populations and using that data to recruit informants and open investigations.

articles.headline: In I.P.O., a Quest to Satisfy China’s Appetite for Pork
articles.snippet: The public offering of WH Group will offer investors a chance to bet on a business that is trying to marry China’s apparently insatiable demand for the meat with the efficiency of American pork production.
articles.abstract: The public offering of WH Group will offer investors a chance to bet on a business that is trying to marry China’s apparently insatiable demand for the meat with the efficiency of American pork production.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — There is a commodity creating ravenous demand among China’s growing consumer class, one whose pricing is so important that it influences the Chinese central bank’s monetary policy. The commerce ministry even maintains strategic reserves and has been piling them higher in recent weeks in an attempt to stabilize prices.

articles.headline: Taking a Risk, Investors Snap Up Once-Shunned Greek Debt
articles.snippet: After investors flocked to its five-year debt offering, Athens said it was a sign that the country was succeeding in turning its economy around.
articles.abstract: After investors flocked to its five-year debt offering, Athens said it was a sign that the country was succeeding in turning its economy around.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Investors shunned Greek bonds at the height of the European economic crisis, fearful that the region’s sickest nation would collapse from its financial woes.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and Landon Thomas Jr

articles.headline: G.M. Places 2 Engineers on Leave in Inquiry
articles.snippet: The company said the two were suspended with pay as an “interim step” in its investigation of ignition problems that persisted for years.
articles.abstract: The company said the two were suspended with pay as an “interim step” in its investigation of ignition problems that persisted for years.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The ignition-switch scandal at General Motors widened on Thursday as the automaker suspended two engineers and added another repair to its recall of cars with a faulty ignition switch that has been linked to 13 deaths.

articles.headline: Fast-Growing Sectors Drive a Market Sell-Off
articles.snippet: Despite strong data on new claims for unemployment, investors were taking defensive positions and selling so-called momentum stocks.
articles.abstract: Despite strong data on new claims for unemployment, investors were taking defensive positions and selling so-called momentum stocks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investors dumped Internet, biotechnology and other fast-growing companies at a dizzying pace on Thursday, dragging down the rest of the stock market and stirring up painful memories of the dot-com bust in 2000.
